results.title: Spotlights: George Miller
results.brief_description: An Australian filmmaker and former physician. He is best known for his Mad Max franchise, whose second instalment, Mad Max 2 (1981), and fourth, Fury Road (2015), have been hailed as among the greatest action films of all time.

constellations_primary.name: George Miller
constellations_primary.description: For a guy who started his career as a physician, George Miller sure is a diverse filmmaker.

results.description: An Australian filmmaker and former physician, George Miller is best known for his Mad Max franchise, whose second instalment, Mad Max 2 (1981), and fourth, Fury Road (2015), have been hailed as among the greatest action films of all time. George discusses storytelling and how it helps us make our way through the world.
description_for_label: An Australian filmmaker and former physician, George Miller is best known for his Mad Max franchise, whose second instalment, Mad Max 2 (1981), and fourth, Fury Road (2015), have been hailed as among the greatest action films of all time. George discusses storytelling and how it helps us make our way through the world.

group.title: Spotlights

results.title: Canopy
results.credit_line:
John Harvey, Saibai Island

Multi-screen installation

Commissioned by ACMI and edited by Patrick McCabe
results.brief_description: John Harvey’s multi-screen installation, Canopy, celebrates and shares First Peoples self-representation while resisting and disrupting popular ideas of Australian identity, place and nationhood too often defined by the white gaze of non-Indigenous filmmakers.

constellations_primary.name: Canopy
constellations_primary.description: John Harvey is a Torres Strait Islander producer, director and writer in screen and stage whose work Canopy celebrates Indigenous self-representation.

results.description:
Throughout the history of screen culture, First Peoples have been portrayed as both an exotic curiosity and stereotypically deficient due to the ‘white gaze’ wielded by non-Indigenous Australians, who often defined First Peoples representation on-screen.

Around the 1970s, First Peoples stepped behind the camera en masse to capture their own story and control their representation, using the lens to return the gaze, look back, and look at each other. While celebrating, practicing and sharing culture, this gaze continues to resist and disrupt popular ideas of Australian identity, place and nationhood.

Canopy continues this tradition and comments on First Peoples self-representation.

“The canopy is teeming with life. It is a place where the biodiversity of species ensures the survival of us all. Through the imagery in my work, I’m exploring layers of being, from the individual to family, clan, culture, country and finally, to consciousness. Canopy invites audiences to still their minds and experience the work as a meditation with an open spirit and heart. It contains my home movies along with films I’ve written and directed.” – John Harvey
description_for_label:

Canopy continues this tradition and comments on First Peoples self-representation.

“The canopy is teeming with life. It is a place where the biodiversity of species ensures the survival of us all. results.title: Spotlights: Ana Kokkinos
results.brief_description: An Australian film and TV director and screenwriter of Greek descent born in Melbourne. Kokkinos has directed three feature-length films and two short films including Head On (1998), The Book of Revelation (2006) and Blessed (2009).

constellations_primary.name: Ana Kokkinos
constellations_primary.description: The films and TV works of Ana Kokkinos often explore the experiences of second-generation Australians, queer identities and class. Since beginning her career in the early 90s, those stories have started to appear more frequently on Australian screens.

results.description: Ana Kokkinos is an Australian filmmaker and screenwriter of Greek descent born in Melbourne. Kokkinos has directed features and two shorts including Head On (1998), The Book of Revelation (2006) and Blessed (2009). Here she discusses diversity, particularly in relation to class and queerness.
description_for_label: Ana Kokkinos is an Australian filmmaker and screenwriter of Greek descent born in Melbourne. Kokkinos has directed features and two shorts including Head On (1998), The Book of Revelation (2006) and Blessed (2009). Here she discusses diversity, particularly in relation to class and queerness.

results.title: Clapperboard (studio of Mirka Mora)
results.brief_description: Clapperboard made from wood and painted black and white, board has cloth tape around middle and bottom sections. Back of board has a piece of paper attached with rows of numbers.

results.title: Did you ask the river?
results.credit_line:
Joan Ross
Mordant Family VR Commission, ACMI Collection
Developed in collaboration with Dr Josh Harle at Tactical Space Lab, Sydney
results.material_description: software, video, props, colour and sound
results.brief_description:
‘Did you ask the river?’ is the debut VR work from one of Australia’s leading visual artists, Joan Ross.

In the style of a first-person videogame, participants are given free rein to explore an interactive 3D extension of Ross’s vibrant, yet unsettling, colonial landscapes.

Unlike many VR experiences, participants are placed in a body – that of an 18th century colonial woman – and become uncomfortably complicit in her unwitting destruction of the landscape.

results.title: Paragon stereoviewer
results.brief_description: Stereoscopic viewers were popular home entertainment in the Victorian era. They let people see 3D engineering wonders, like new skyscrapers and railroads, as well as sightseeing slides from across the natural world.
results.description:
Three-dimensional images have been around for more than 180 years – they just weren’t called ‘3D’. Stereoscopic images are two separate pictures with slightly different perspectives. A stereoscopic viewer mimics how we see so that the two images converge into a single three-dimensional picture.

British inventor Charles Wheatstone discovered this process in 1838 and used a device as big as a table to make it work. Another British scientist, David Brewster, later simplified and shrank the viewer into a portable, hand-held device.

Stereoscopic viewers were popular home entertainment in the Victorian era. They let people see 3D engineering wonders, like new skyscrapers and railroads, as well as sightseeing slides from across the natural world.
description_for_label:

results.title: Motion pictures. 1st 20 years. Part 1: 1898-1903
results.brief_description:
A compilation of silent films from 1898-1903. Films restored from the Library of Congress paper prints.
Contents: Elopement on horseback (1898)—Strange adventure of N.Y. Drummer (1899)—Uncle Josh’s nightmare (1900)—Terrible Teddy, the grizzly king (1901)—Love by the light of the moon (1901)—Panarama of esplanade by night (1901)—Martyred presidents (1901)—Uncle Josh at the moving picture show (1902)—Fun in a bakery shop (1902)—Jack and the beanstalk (1902)— Life of an American fireman (1903)

results.title: Minyak Sawit Keluarga (Palm Oil Family)
results.brief_description: Minyak Sawit Keluarga (Palm Oil Family) by artist Olivia Koh, examines her paternal family’s history of farming practices in rural Southern Malaysia (Peninsula). Footage of domestic-scale palm oil plantations in Johor is interspersed with visual and auditory recordings of funerary Daoist rituals, documents and interviews that consider the palm oil industry and relevant history of migration in the local area.
results.description: Minyak Sawit Keluarga (Palm Oil Family) by artist Olivia Koh, examines her paternal family’s history of farming practices in rural Southern Malaysia (Peninsula). results.title: The Gods of Tiny Things
results.credit_line:
Deborah Kelly

Two-channel digital animation, colour, sound

ACMI Collection

Collage figures: Joanne Albany, Alana Ambados, Kate Andrews, Justin Ashworth, Kathryn Bird, Karen Golland, Amanda Holt, Deborah Kelly, Kath Lim, Lex Lindsay, Megan Rushton, Rie Tamaoke, Anna Tregloan
results.brief_description: Deborah Kelly’s The Gods of Tiny Things is a vast, microscopic Eden teeming with deities born from the pages of old magazines and encyclopaedias, creating an exquisite collage of grotesque beauty and new mythologies.

constellations_primary.name: Speculative futures, sci-fi worlds and environmental disaster
constellations_primary.description: Deborah Kelly's The Gods of Tiny Things explores extinction and the climate crisis, the scars of colonialism, and the political shift to the right around the world through collage and imagined futures, much like these sci-fi, animated and computer-generated artworks.

results.description:
“This work is blessed by the powers of the animator, musicians and collagists. Having such creative collaborators is the treasure of my life.” – Deborah Kelly

The Gods of Tiny Things is a vast, microscopic Eden teeming with deities born from the pages of old magazines and encyclopedias, creating an exquisite collage of grotesque beauty and new mythologies. Combining the divine, mundane and profane, these celestial creations animate a kaleidoscopic symbology that explores extinction and the climate crisis, the scars of colonialism, and the political shift to the right around the world, while simultaneously revelling in the persistence of pleasure, desire and life. Created at ‘collage camp’ at Bundanon on beautiful Yuin Country, this collaborative work is a poetic and urgent warning.

Deborah Kelly is a Sydney-based artist whose works have been shown around Australia, and in the Biennales of Singapore, Sydney, Thessaloniki, TarraWarra and Venice. Her projects across media are concerned with lineages of representation, politics and history in public exchange, and practices of collectivity on small and large scale, both fleeting and durational. Her newest works experiment with models of sustained creative collaboration between strangers. Kelly’s moving image artworks have been shown around the world, in galleries, cinemas and projected onto rock formations, buildings and clouds.
description_for_label: The Gods of Tiny Things is a vast, microscopic Eden teeming with deities born from the pages of old magazines and encyclopedias, creating an exquisite collage of grotesque beauty and new mythologies. Combining the divine, mundane and profane, these celestial creations animate a kaleidoscopic symbology that explores extinction and the climate crisis, the scars of colonialism, and the political shift to the right around the world, while simultaneously revelling in the persistence of pleasure, desire and life.

results.title: Jaara Nyilamum
results.creator_credit: Lou Bennett AM and Romaine Moreton
results.credit_line:
Dr Romaine Moreton (Goenpul Yagerabul Minjungbal Bundjalung) and Dr Lou Bennett AM (Dja Dja Wurrung, Yorta Yorta)

Single-channel video, 7.39 mins

Filmed and edited by Dr Romaine Moreton

Co-directed by Dr Romaine Moreton and Dr Lou Bennett AM

Jaara Nyilamum (song composition) Performed by Dr Lou Bennett AM and the Australian String Quartet

Composed by Dr Lou Bennett AM

Arranged by Iain Grandage

Produced by Stephen Snelleman

Engineered by Russell Thomson

ACMI Collection
results.brief_description:
“The making of “Jaara Nyilamum” (2021) evoked a stillness that restored us to full sensual immersion within Country, and from this place of rooted calmness, Country reaffirmed our Law is real. “Jaara Nyilamum” became most profound when we realised this was more than a film about ceremony, but was in fact, ceremony itself. Our challenge was to create a production model that aligned with our beliefs and centralised our Law, pushed back against monochronic time and engaged with the deep cycles of place, where we embraced Belonging as a process of constant renewal and Rematration.” – Dr Lou Bennett AM and Dr Romaine Moreton

Dr Lou Bennett is a performer, songwriter, musical and artistic director, composer, actor, soundscape designer and academic. Lou’s research project ‘Sovereign Language Rematriation Through Song Pedagogy’ focusses on the importance and relevance of Indigenous language retrieval, reclamation, and regeneration through the medium of the arts to enhance community health and wellbeing.

Dr Romaine Moreton is an artist, writer, performer, filmmaker, and her proposes an Indigenous philosophy of storytelling and embodied knowledge, with her work constantly drawing our attention back to the importance of the breath in Indigenous cultural practices.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Dr Romaine Moreton (Goenpul Yagerabul Minjungbal Bundjalung), Dr Lou Bennett AM (Dja Dja Wurrung, Yorta Yorta)
